Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Minimally Invasive Robotic Non-Destructive Evaluation and Rehabilitation for Bridge Decks (Bridge-MINDER)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bridges are critical components of modern transportation infrastructure. Bridges deteriorate over time as a result of material aging, excessive use and overloading, environmental conditions, inadequate maintenance, and deficiencies in inspection and evaluation. Building on the recent advances in robotics and automation technologies, the objective of this project is to develop a novel Minimally Invasive robotic Non-Destructive Evaluation and Rehabilitation for bridge decks.

The project develops new robotic system, algorithms and control schemes for sustainable civil infrastructure, including (1) development of a novel robotics-assisted in-traffic system for highly-efficient, safety-guaranteed bridge deck inspection and diagnosis; (2) development of a new robotic rehabilitation system for delivering fast, cost-effective, minimally invasive repair and maintenance for bridge decks; (3) a human-in-the-loop robotic coordination for minimally traffic interference; and (4) experimental platforms and field performance evaluation for the proposed system. The project also provides insights to advance real time scene understanding, multiple robot coordination, and human-robot collaboration in complex robotic systems. If successful, this project can drastically reduce bridge maintenance cost and mitigate negative impact caused by closing the bridge traffic flow under traditional bridge inspection and repair. The project outcomes, including source code, datasets, and publications, are to be shared among research community and the general public. The project also includes a number of integrated research and education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering and involve students into robotics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bridges are one of the infrastructure components critical for the safety of the traveling public and the sustainability of economic activities. Bridges deteriorate over time as a result of material aging, excessive use and overloading, environmental conditions, inadequate maintenance, and deficiencies in inspection and evaluation. The financial cost of repairing and replacing deteriorating highway bridges and the potential social impact of the deteriorating infrastructure to the general public are enormous. The objective of this NRI project is to develop a novel Minimally Invasive robotic Non-Destructive Evaluation and Rehabilitation for bridge decks (Bridge-MINDER).

The PIs tackled these challenges by developing new robotic system, algorithms and control schemes in Bridge-MINDER. Specifically, this NRI project emphasizes on:

1)      development of a novel robotics-assisted in-traffic Nondestructive evaluation (NDE) system for highly-efficient, safety-guaranteed bridge deck inspection and diagnosis;

2)      development of a new robotic rehabilitation system for delivering fast, cost-effective, minimally invasive repair and maintenance for bridge decks;

3)      a human-in-the-loop robotic coordination for minimally traffic interference; and experimental platforms and field performance evaluation for Bridge-MINDERS.

 

This is a collaborative project between Rutgers University (Lead Institution) and Texas A&M University (TAMU). At TAMU side, our specific focuses have been the following,

1)      Multi-sensor platform calibration scheme: calibrating the relative coordinate systems among the Ground penetration radar (GPR), the laser ranger finder (LiDAR), and the camera is the first step before sensor fusion.   

2)      Sensor fusion for mapping of cracks for bridge decks. Subsurface data from GRP and surface data from the camera and the LiDAR are fused to form a 3D visualization of bridge decks, this can be viewed as a multi-sensor simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM).

3)      In-Traffic NDE, we have develop algorithms to distinguish bridge surface from moving surrounding traffic.

 

In the four year research, we have put together an interdisciplinary research team. We have built a unique testbed which integrates a GPR, a camera, and a Lidar. We have obtained both theoretical results and physical experiment results. Working with local governments, we have tested our results in real world settings. We addressed the aforementioned research problems and published over 10 journal and conference papers in well recognized and referred venues. The results have been well received by research community and the general public. The process allowed us to train two post docs, six Ph.D. students, and many M.S. and ungraduated students. Our projects have been reflected in classroom projects and outreach to minority and underrepresented groups.
